review.title: Frugal Bribery in Voting
review.abstract: Bribery in elections is an important problem in computational social choice theory. However, bribery with money is often illegal in elections. Motivated by this, we introduce the notion of frugal bribery and formulate two new pertinent computational problems which we call Frugal-bribery and Frugal- $bribery to capture bribery without money in elections. In the proposed model, the briber is frugal in nature and this is captured by her inability to bribe votes of a certain kind, namely, non-vulnerable votes. In the Frugal-bribery problem, the goal is to make a certain candidate win the election by changing only vulnerable votes. In the Frugal-{dollar}bribery problem, the vulnerable votes have prices and the goal is to make a certain candidate win the election by changing only vulnerable votes, subject to a budget constraint of the briber. We further formulate two natural variants of the Frugal-{dollar}bribery problem namely Uniform-frugal-{dollar}bribery and Nonuniform-frugal-{dollar}bribery where the prices of the vulnerable votes are, respectively, all the same or different.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In a typical electoral scenario, we have a set of candidates and a set of voters who report their preferences or votes that constitute a complete ranking of candidates. An electoral rule is a process that selects a candidate as the winner based on a collection of votes. A set of votes over a set of candidates along with an electoral rule is called an electoral rule. Activities that attempt to influence voter opinion in favor of particular candidates are very common during the time an election is in progress. An extreme illustration of this phenomenon is bribery - where candidates can conduct elaborate campaigns to promote themselves among a general or targeted audience. Likewise, it is not uncommon for people to protest against or rally for a national committee or court that is in the process of approving a particular policy. An extreme illustration of this phenomenon is bribery - where candidates can create financial incentives to influence voters. Of course, the process of influencing voters can be falsifying.

sections.heading: 1.1 Motivation and Contributions
sections.text: We believe that this perspective of voter influence is somewhat more complicated than the existing models of the bribery problem. Also, most of the general cost models examined in the literature have absolute costs per election-candidate combination, with no specific consideration of voters "views of the current winner. We present a model in which changing the results of the vote is relatively easy to do, if the winner of the election achieves a result that the winner of the election would claim for himself, then this is a change that the voter is likely to like to make, while the change does not cause their favorite candidate to win the election, to improve it from their point of view (namely, that their least favorite candidate wins the election).

sections.heading: 1.2 Related Work
sections.text: The pioneering work of Faliszewski et al. [Faliszewski et al., 2006] defined and examined the $bribery problem, where the input is a series of votes with the prizes for each vote, and the goal is to let an excellent candidate win the election subject to a budget constraint of the bribe. The $bribe problem is the $bribe problem, with the caveat that the price for each non-vulnerable vote is infinite. Also, the $bribe problem is a specialization of the $bribe problem. So, whenever the $bribe problem is mathematically simple in an environment, both the $bribe problem and the $bribe problem are mathematically simple (see Proposition 1 for more formal proof). However, the $bribe problem is mathematically insolvable in most settings, and this leaves the computational complexity of the Proposition problem of bribery and the electability problem to solve.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed and examined an elaborate model of bribery. It turns out that the problems examined in this paper have interesting links to two of the best-studied problems in the theory of computerized social choice, namely manipulation and $bribery. We believe that our work also has practical appeal, while it is interesting from a purely theoretical viewpoint. A potential and natural direction for future work is to examine these problems under various other conditions. An obvious attitude is to limit the campaigner's knowledge of the votes and / or the candidates who will actually appear. Uncertainty may also stem from the voting rule that will ultimately be used in a number of voting rules. Also, investigating these problems, if the price model for vulnerable votes resembles the swap bribery, would be another interesting future direction. However, it is not very clear whether a swap bribery model like the price model has any practical motivation for fixing money without bribery.

metadata.abstractText: Bribery in elections is an important problem in computational social choice theory. However, bribery with money is often illegal in elections. Motivated by this, we introduce the notion of frugal bribery and formulate two new pertinent computational problems which we call Frugal-bribery and Frugal$bribery to capture ‘bribery without money’ in elections. In the proposed model, the briber is frugal in nature and this is captured by her inability to bribe votes of a certain kind, namely, non-vulnerable votes. In the Frugal-bribery problem, the goal is to make a certain candidate win the election by changing only vulnerable votes. In the Frugal-$bribery problem, the vulnerable votes have prices and the goal is to make a certain candidate win the election by changing only vulnerable votes, subject to a budget constraint of the briber. We further formulate two natural variants of the Frugal-$bribery problem namely Uniform-frugal-$bribery and Nonuniform-frugal-$bribery where the prices of the vulnerable votes are, respectively, all the same or different. We study the computational complexity of the above problems for unweighted and weighted elections for several commonly used voting rules. We observe that, even if we have only a small number of candidates, the problems are intractable for all voting rules studied here for weighted elections, with the sole exception of the Frugal-bribery problem for the plurality voting rule. In contrast, we have polynomial time algorithms for the Frugal-bribery problem for plurality, veto, k-approval, k-veto, and plurality with runoff voting rules for unweighted elections. However, the Frugal-$bribery problem is intractable for all the voting rules studied here barring the plurality and the veto voting rules for unweighted elections.
